sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: Avonex(R), 30 mcg IM once weekly, OR, initial, 7.5 mcg IM on week 1, then increase dose by 7.5 mcg each week until 30 mcg once weekly is reached; pretreatment with analgesics or antipyretics on injection days may decrease flu-like symptoms
  • Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: Rebif(R) titration to 22 mcg dose: initial, 4.4 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week for weeks 1 and 2; increase to 11 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week for weeks 3 and 4, then 22 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week
  • Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms: Rebif(R) titration to 44 mcg dose: initial, 8.8 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week for weeks 1 and 2; increase to 22 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week for weeks 3 and 4, then 44 mcg SUBQ 3 times/week

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in pediatric patients under 18 years of age

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatric: initiate with lower dose, use caution

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Multiple sclerosis, Relapsing forms
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Multiple sclerosis, Clinically Isolated Syndrome

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to human albumin (Avonex(R) lyophilized powder vial and Rebif(R) prefilled syringes)
  • hypersensitivity to natural or recombinant interferon beta or to any other component of the formulation

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular
  • -- cardiac toxicity, including congestive heart failure and cardiomyopathy with or without congestive heart failure, have been reported in patients with no predisposition to these events
  • -- worsening of preexisting congestive heart failure may occur during initiation and continued treatment; monitoring recommended
  • Dermatologic
  • -- injection site reactions, including necrosis, have been reported with subQ administration, sometimes long after therapy initiation; monitoring of self-injection recommended
  • Endocrine
  • -- new or worsening thyroid dysfunction has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic
  • -- decreased peripheral blood counts, including pancytopenia, have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Hepatic
  • -- active or past significant liver disease or dysfunction, or alcohol abuse; dosage reduction may be needed
  • -- hepatic injury, including hepatic failure and asymptomatic elevation of hepatic transaminases, has been reported; monitoring recommended; dosage reduction or discontinuation of therapy may be needed
  • Immunologic
  • -- anaphylaxis and allergic reactions, some cases after prolonged use, have been reported
  • -- autoimmune disorders (eg, idiopathic thrombocytopenia, hyper- and hypothyroidism, autoimmune hepatitis) have been reported; monitoring recommended and therapy discontinuation should be considered
  • -- latex sensitivity; syringe tip cap contains latex
  • Neurologic
  • -- seizures have been reported, sometimes in patients with no prior history; use caution in patients with preexisting seizure disorders
  • Psychiatric
  • -- depression, suicidal ideation and suicide, or new development or worsening of psychiatric disorders, including psychosis, have been reported; consider discontinuation if depression or other severe psychiatric symptoms develop

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (3% to 92%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (8% to 22%), Nausea (23%)
  • Hepatic:Abnormal liver function (4% to 9%), ALT/SGPT level raised (20% to 27%), AST/SGOT level raised (10% to 17%), Hyperbilirubinemia (2% to 3%)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development (5% to 31%), Autoimmune hepatitis, Lymphadenopathy (11% to 12%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Backache (23% to 25%), Musculoskeletal pain (10% to 15%), Myalgia (25% to 29%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (24%), Dizziness (14%), Headache (58% to 70%)
  • Ophthalmic:Abnormal vision (7% to 13%)
  • Psychiatric:Depression (18%)
  • Renal:Urinary tract infectious disease (17%)
  • Respiratory:Sinusitis (14%), Upper respiratory infection (14%)
  • Other:Fatigue (33% to 41%), Fever (20% to 28%), Influenza-like symptoms (49% to 59%), Pain (23%), Shivering (19%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiomyopathy, Congestive heart failure
  • Dermatologic:Injection site necrosis (1% to 3%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (3% to 5%), Leukopenia (up to 36%), Pancytopenia, Thrombocytopenia (2% to 8%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatotoxicity, Injury of liver (rare), Liver failure (rare)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (rare), Hypersensitivity reaction, Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Neurologic:Seizure (4% to 5%)
  • Ophthalmic:Retinal vascular disorder
  • Psychiatric:Suicidal thoughts

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Interferon beta-1a is a purified glycoprotein which has an identical amino acid sequence as natural fibroblast-derived human interferon beta. Interferons are cytokines that mediate antiviral, antiproliferative, and immunomodulatory activities. The mechanism of action of interferon beta-1a in the treatment of multiple sclerosis is unknown.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intramuscular
    • Avonex(R) should be given via IM administration
    • vial, prefilled syringe, and prefilled autoinjector are all single-use only
    • reconstitute vials with sterile water for injection to concentration of 30 mcg/mL
    • use reconstituted vials immediately or within 6 hours if refrigerated at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F)
    • (prefilled syringe, prefilled autoinjector) warm to room temperature for 30 minutes; do not use external heat sources to warm (eg, hot water)
    • (prefilled syringe, prefilled autoinjector) once removed from the refrigerator, may store at 77 degrees F (25 degrees C) or lower and administer within 7 days
    • rotate injection sites; do not inject in areas where skin is irritated, reddened, bruised, infected, or scarred in any way
    • check injection site after 2 hours for signs of redness, swelling, or tenderness
  • Subcutaneous
    • Rebif(R) should be given via subQ administration.
    • may be warmed at room temperature for 30 minutes prior to administration
    • allow at least 48 hours between injections; give at same time of day, preferably late afternoon or evening, on the same 3 days each week; rotate injection sites
    • use only prefilled syringes for titration to 22 mcg; prefilled syringes or autoinjector may be used for titration to 44 mcg
    • single use only; discard unused portion use

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• delay in the progression of disability and a decrease in the frequency of exacerbations are indicative of a therapeutic response
  • changes in MRI studies may indicate improvement
  • blood chemistries; during therapy
  • CBC with differential 1, 3, and 6 months after initiation of therapy, then periodically; more frequent monitoring may be required for patients with myelosuppression
  • liver function tests 1, 3, and 6 months after initiation of therapy, then periodically
  • thyroid function tests; every 6 months in patients with a history of thyroid dysfunction or as clinically indicated
  • cardiac disease worsening; during initiation and continued treatment, in patients with preexisting congestive heart failure
  • signs and symptoms of decreased blood counts and hepatic injury
  • seizures, especially in patients with preexisting disorders
  • self-injection technique periodically, especially if injection-site necrosis has previously occurred

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Avonex
    • Intramuscular Kit: 30 MCG
    • Kit: 30 MCG/0.5 ML
  • Avonex Pen
    Kit: 30 MCG/0.5 ML
  • Rebif Rebidose
    Subcutaneous Solution: 22 MCG/0.5 ML, 44 MCG/0.5 ML
  • Rebif
    Subcutaneous Solution: 22 MCG/0.5 ML, 44 MCG/0.5 ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
OVERDOSE: Data are limited. Shivers, myalgias, low grade fever and tachycardia have been reported. ADVERSE EFFECTS: "flu-like" symptoms (fever, chills, tachycardia, headache, malaise, and myalgias), hypotension, seizures, headache, lethargy, fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, & renal insufficiency; dysrhythmias in patients with underlying heart disease. Vomiting, diarrhea, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia occur at high doses.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
  • Decontamination: Not indicated; broken down in the gut on oral ingestion.
  • Influenza-like illness: Treat with acetaminophen or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents
  • Hypotensive episode: Transient, usually requires no treatment; 0.9% NaCl 10-20 ml/kg, dopamine, epinephrine if persistent
  • Monitoring of patient: CBC, hepatic & renal function; ECG, calcium, potassium if severe overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
INTERFERONS
Single doses greater than 100-200 million units associated with toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report depression, suicidal ideation, or unusual changes in behavior.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of infection or hepatotoxicity.
  • Counsel patient to report symptoms of congestive heart failure or cardiomyopathy.
  • Side effects may include headache, flu-like symptoms, fever, myalgia, fatigue, asthenia, or injection site reactions.
  • Warn patient to report seizures.
  • If self-administered, instruct patient on proper technique for injection.
  • Avonex(R): Tell patient with latex sensitivity that the prefilled syringe tip cap contains natural rubber latex.
  • Rebif(R): Advise patient to give injections at the same time of day (late afternoon or evening), on the same 3 days each week, and at least 48 hours apart.
